Oh gosh, Ray and I and Sue and Buddy took a trip to Mexico City. It must have been four or six months after my dad died. That's how I remember it. He died in December of 67. Sometime in 68, we took this trip. We've been talking about it for a while. Flew down to Mexico City. We, I think it was the name of my hotel, which wouldn't mean anything now, but we ended up in a fabulous hotel. First night, very unhappy with our rooms. We're getting down now. And the next morning, Buddy, who's an early riser, anyhow, he was probably up at four o'clock, and he went down there and complained to the manager. So, because it was not the accommodation we were supposed to have had, we checked in at eight o'clock at night or so, which is, in Mexico, it was like, you know. Well, we ended up with a corner suite with, it was so big, we could have a party for 50 people and invested three bathrooms in it. Two bedrooms, so they had, but they had an extra guest bathroom with a big bar. It was open on two sides, because we didn't have everybody there for two hours. And I remember the New York Yankees were training there, so it probably was season opens in April, so it probably was February or March. Mickey Mantle and Whitey Ford and all of them. I wish I had been smart enough to know them. These baseball cards and autographs would be selling for three or four hundred dollars, but at any rate, I went down there with a recorder. And if you ever been to Mexico City and did a ride in some kind of city about 100 miles away, I thought we were going to die going down to an old car. Anyway. For this guy, he was very successful. But it was an art company and there were a lot of Americans down there. He was not an American.
